summary: This document contains the Articles of Incorporation for Financial Trust Company, Inc., a corporation established in the U.S. Virgin Islands. It outlines the company's broad business purposes, corporate structure, and lists its initial incorporators and resident agent. The document is part of the JPMorgan Chase document set related to the Epstein case. This document contains the Articles of Incorporation for Financial Trust Company, Inc., a Virgin Islands corporation, dated 1998, and a J.P. Morgan Account Entity Power of Attorney form dated 2010. The Articles list the incorporators and corporate purposes, while the power of attorney form grants broad financial authority to an attorney-in-fact over J.P. Morgan accounts. This document contains the Articles of Incorporation and By-Laws for Financial Trust Company, Inc., a corporation established in the U.S. Virgin Islands. It details corporate governance, stock issuance, director and officer powers, and includes signatures of incorporators. The document is part of the JPMorgan Chase document production related to the Epstein case, likely concerning financial structures. This document contains corporate records for Financial Trust Company, Inc., a Virgin Islands corporation, including its by-laws, director/officer resolutions, and account application forms with J.P. Morgan. It shows changes in corporate leadership following Jeffrey Epstein's resignation and establishes authorized signatories for financial accounts.

The corporation's stated purpose includes providing financial counseling and investment advice, serving as a trustee/fiduciary, and conducting business globally.
The initial incorporators were Barbara Mignon Weatherly, Jennit-lynn Falk, and Daie R Michael, all residents of St. Thomas, Virgin Islands.
Paul Hoffman is named as the corporation's resident agent at its principal office in St. Thomas.
